attr.q: A discrete category is one that has objects but no morphisms other than identity morphisms. How does the Yoneda lemma work for functors from such a category?
attr.a: Let \eta be a natural transformation from hom(X, -) to F X. \eta_X is a function of \eta_X : hom(X,X) \rightarrow F X. Since hom(X,X) is a singleton set, there are different \eta_X as many as the cardinality of F X. In the mean time there is only one kind of \eta_A, the absurd function , for any other component than X because hom(X, A) is empty. Therefore there are different \eta as many as F A.
